turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I insist--and a beaker for Mr. Marlowe. The BARMAN does the business.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I hear you have a new play for the Curtain.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Not new--my Doctor Faustus.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I love your early work. "Was this the face that launched a thousand ships and burnt the topless towers of Ilium?"

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: I have a new one nearly done, and better. The Massacre at Paris.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Good title.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: And yours?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter.  Yes, I know.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: What is the story?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well, there's a pirate  In truth, I have not written a word.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Romeo isItalian. Always in and out of love.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes, that's good. Until he meets

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Ethel.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you think?

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: The daughter of his enemy.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The daughter of his enemy.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: His best friend is killed in a duel by Ethel's brother or something. His name is Mercutio.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Mercutiogood name.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Good luck with yours, Kit.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: I thought your play was for Burbage.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: This is a different one.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: A different one you haven't written?

turns.speaker: NOL AS BENVOLIO
turns.text: "Good morrow, cousin."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Is the day so young?"

turns.speaker: NOL AS BENVOLIO
turns.text: "But new struck nine."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Ay me, sad hours seem long. Was that my father that went hence so fast?"

turns.speaker: NOL AS BENVOLIO
turns.text: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?"

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Not having that which, having, makes them short."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Out."

turns.speaker: NOL AS BENVOLIO
turns.text: "Of love?"

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Out of her favour where I am in love."

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Two hours at prayer!

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Lady Viola is pious, my lord.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Piety is for Sunday! And two hours at prayer is not piety, it is self- importance!

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: It would be better that you return tomorrow, my lord.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: It would be better that you tell her to get off her knees and show some civility to her six-day lord and master.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Not ready? Where is she?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Be patient, my lord, she is dressing.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Will you ask Her Majesty to be patient?!

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Be good to her, my lord!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: God bless you!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Thank you. Let go, there's a good nurse.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Did you like Proteus or Valentine best? Proteus for speaking, Valentine for looks.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: I liked the dog, for laughs.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But Silvia I did not care for much. His fingers were red from fighting and he spoke like a schoolboy at lessons. Stage love will never be true love while the law of the land has our heroines played by pipsqueak boys in petticoats! Oh, when can we see another?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: When the Queen commands it.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But at the playhouse. Nurse?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Be still.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Playhouses are not for well-born ladies.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I am not so well-born.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Well-monied is the same as well-born and well-married is more so. Lord Wessex was looking at you tonight.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: All the men at court are without poetry. If they look at me they see my father's fortune. I will have poetry in my life. And adventure. And love. Love above all.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Like Valentine and Silvia?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: No . . . not the artful postures of love, but love that over- throws life. Unbiddable, ungovernable, like a riot in the heart, and nothing to be done, come ruin or rapture. Love like there has never been in a play.  I will have love or I will end my days as a . . .

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: As a nurse.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But I would be Valentine and Silvia too. Good Nurse, God save you and good night. I would stay asleep my whole life if I could dream myself into a company of players.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: He sees himself in me! Romeo Montague, a young man of Verona.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Verona again.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: A comedy of quarreling families reconciled in the discovery of Romeo to be the very same Capulet cousin stolen from the cradle and fostered to manhood by his Montague mother that was robbed of her own child by the Pirate King!

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Your mother, and your father

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: From tomorrow, away in the country for three weeks! Is Master Shakespeare not handsome?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: He looks well enough for a mountebank.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh, Nurse! He would give Thomas Kent the life of Viola De Lesseps's dreaming.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: My lady, this play will end badly. I will tell.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You will not tell. As you love me and as I love you, you will bind my breast and buy me a boy's wig!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Your Majesty.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Stand up straight, girl.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: I have seen you. You are the one who comes to all the plays--at Whitehall, at Richmond.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Your Majesty.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: What do you love so much?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Your Majesty

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Speak out! I know who I am. Do you love stories of kings and queens? Feats of arms? Or is it courtly love?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I love theatre. To have stories acted for me by a company of fellows is indeed

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: They are not acted for you, they are acted for me.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: And--?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: And I love poetry above all.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Above Lord Wessex?

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: But playwrights teach nothing about love, they make it pretty, they make it comical, or they make it lust. They cannot make it true.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh, but they can!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Your Majesty

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: There was a wager, I rememberas to whether a play can show the very truth and nature of love. I think you lost it today.  You are an eager boy. Did you like the play?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Your Majesty!

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Why, Lord Wessex! Lost your wife so soon?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Indeed I am a bride short. How is this to end?

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: As stories must when love's denied--with tears and a journey. Those whom God has joined in marriage, not even I can put asunder.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Lord Wessex, as I foretold, has lost his wife in the play- house--go make your farewell and send her out. It's time to settle accounts.  How much was the wager?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Fifty shillings.  Pounds.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Give it to Master Kent. He will see it rightfully home. WESSEX gives his purse to VIOLA.

turns.speaker: RALPH AS NURSE
turns.text: "I know not."

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "Go ask his name--If he be married, My grave is like to be my wedding bed."

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "All my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay, And follow thee my lord throughout the world."

turns.speaker: RALPH AS NURSE
turns.text: "Madam!"

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "I come, anon--But if thou meanest not well, I do beseech thee--"

turns.speaker: RALPH AS NURSE
turns.text: "Madam!"

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: By and by I come to cease thy strife and leave me to my grief. A thousand times good night!"

turns.speaker: ROSALINE
turns.text: When will you write me a sonnet, Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have lost my gift.

turns.speaker: ROSALINE
turns.text: You left it in my bed. Come to look for it again.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Are you to be my muse, ROSALINE?

turns.speaker: ROSALINE
turns.text: Burbage has my keeping but you have my heart.

turns.speaker: ROSALINE
turns.text: Will!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I would have made you immortal.  Tell Burbage he has lost a new play by Will Shakespeare.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Mr. Pope! Mr. Phillips! Welcome, George Bryan! James Armitage!  Sam! My pretty one! Are you ready to fall in love again?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I am, Master Shakespeare.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: But your voice  Have they dropped?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No, no, a touch of cold only. We suspect he is lying but WILL has turned away.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Master Henslowe, you have your actors.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Master Shakespeare

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Luck be with you, Sam.  Sam?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It is not my fault, Master Shakespeare. I could do it yesterday.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Sam! Do me a speech, do me a line.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: "Parting is such sweet sorrow"

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?"

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "Ay pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Oh then, dear saint, let lips do what hands to: They pray: grant thou, lest faith turn to despair."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purg'd."

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "Then have my lips the sin that they have took."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "Sin from my lips? Oh trespass sweetly urg'd. Give me my sin again."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars As daylight doth a lamp. Her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night. See how she leans her cheek upon her hand. O that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek.

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "Ay me."

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "She speaks.

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: I would not for the world!

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: I have night's cloak to hide me from their eyes; And but thou love me, let them find me here.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?"

turns.speaker: SAM AS JULIET
turns.text: "What satisfaction can'st thou have tonight?"

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS ROMEO
turns.text: "The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine."

turns.speaker: SIR ROBERT
turns.text: She is a beauty, my lord, as would take a king to church for a dowry of a nutmeg.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: My plantations in Virginia are not mortgaged for a nutmeg. I have an ancient name that will bring you preferment when your grandson is a Wessex. Is she fertile?

turns.speaker: SIR ROBERT
turns.text: She will breed. If she do not, send her back.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Is she obedient?

turns.speaker: SIR ROBERT
turns.text: As any mule in Christendom. But if you are the man to rider her, their are rubies in the saddlebag.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: I like her.

turns.speaker: TILNEY
turns.text: Like you, I found him not at home!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So this is the favour you find in the Chamberlain's Men.

turns.speaker: TILNEY
turns.text: What does Burbage care of that? He is readying the Curtain for Kit Marlowe.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You have opened the playhouses?

turns.speaker: TILNEY
turns.text: I have, Master Shakespeare.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: But the plague

turns.speaker: TILNEY
turns.text: Yes, I know. But he was always hanging around the house.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Who are you, master?

turns.speaker: URCHIN
turns.text: I am Ethel, sir, the Pirate's daughter.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'll be damned if you are!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Better fortune, boy.

turns.speaker: URCHIN
turns.text: I was in a play. They cut my head off in Titus Andronicus. When I write plays, they will be like Titus.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You admire it?

turns.speaker: URCHIN
turns.text: I like it when they cut heads off. And the daughter mutilated with knives.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh. What is your name?

turns.speaker: URCHIN
turns.text: Wait, you'll see the cat bites his head off.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have to get back.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: My lady!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Who is there?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Will Shakespeare!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Anon, good nurse. Anon.  Master Shakespeare?!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The same, alas.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh but why "alas?"

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A lowly player.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Alas indeed, for I thought you the highest poet of my esteem and a writer of plays that capture my heart.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh--I am him too!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh my lady, my love!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: If they find you here they will kill you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You can bring them with a word.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh, not for the world!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Can you love a fool?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Can you love a player?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Wait! You are still a maid and perhaps as mistook in me as I was mistook in Thomas Kent.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Answer me only this: are you the author of the plays of William Shakespeare?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I am.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Then kiss me again for I am not mistook.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I do not know how to undress a man.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It is strange to me, too.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I would not have thought it. There is something better than a play.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: There is.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Even your play.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: And that was only my first try.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well perhaps better than my first.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You would not leave me?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I must. Look-- how pale the window.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Moonlight!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No, the morning rooster woke me.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: It was the owl--come to bed

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, let Henslowe wait.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Mr. Henslowe?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Let him be damned for his pages!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh--no, no!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: There is time. It is still dark.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: It is broad day!  The rooster tells us so!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It was the owl. Believe me, love, it was the owl.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh, do not go

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I must. I must

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh, Will!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes, some of it is speakable.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: "Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast. O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?"

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: That's my line!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, but it is mine too!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I found something in my sleep. The Friar who married them will take up their destinies.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Oh, but it will end well for love?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: In heaven, perhaps. It is not a comedy I am writing now. A broad river divides my lovers--family, duty, fate--as unchangeable as nature.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Yes, this is not life, Will. This is a stolen season.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You cannot! Not for the Queen herself!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: What will you have me do? Marry you instead?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: To be the wife of a poor player?--can I wish that for Lady Viola, except in my dreams? And yet I would, if I were free to follow my desire in the harsh light of day.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You follow your desire freely enough in the night. So, if that is all, to Greenwich I go.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Then I will go with you.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You cannot, Wessex will kill you

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know how to fight!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Stage fighting!  Oh, Will! As Thomas Kent my heart belongs to you but as Viola the river divides us, and I will marry Wessex a week from Saturday.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Will! What--?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A literary feud. Quite normal.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Marlowe's touch was in my Titus Andronicus and my Henry VI was a house built on his foundations.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You never spoke so well of him.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: He was not dead before. I would exchange all my plays to come for all of his that will never come.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You lie.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You lie in your meadow as you lied in my bed.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: My love is no lie. I have a wife, yes, and I cannot marry the daughter of Sir Robert de Lesseps. It needed no wife come from Stratford to tell you that. And yet you let me come to your bed.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Calf love. I loved the writer, and gave up the prize for a sonnet.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I was the more deceived.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I love you, Will, beyond poetry.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, my love  You ran from me before.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You were not dead before. When I thought you dead, I did not care about all the plays that will never come, only that I would never see your face. I saw our end, and it will come.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You cannot marry Wessex!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: If not Wessex the Queen will know the cause and there will be no more Will Shakespeare.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Nono.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But I will go to Wessex as a widow from these vows, as solemn as they are unsanctified.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Will you read it for me?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: "Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day> It was the nightingale and not the lark That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear. Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate tree. Believe me, love, it was the nightingale."

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: "It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale. Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east. Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die."

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: "thou need'st not to be gone."

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: "I have more care to stay than will to go. Come death, and welcome. Juliet wills it so. How is't my soul? Let's talk. It is not day."

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: A hired player no longer. Fifty pounds, Will, for the poet of true love.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I am done with theatre. The playhouse is for dreamers. Look where the dream has brought us.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: It was we ourselves did that. And for my life to come I would not have it otherwise.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have hurt you and I am sorry for it.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: If my hurt is to be that you will write no more, then I shall be the sorrier.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: The Queen commands a comedy, Will for Twelfth Night.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A comedy! What will my hero be but the saddest wretch in the kingdom, sick with love?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: An excellent beginning  Let him bea duke. And your heroine?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Sold in marriage and half way to America.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: At sea, then--a voyage to a new world?she lands upon a vast and empty shore. She is brought to the dukeOrsino.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Orsinogood name

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But fearful of her virtue, she comes to him dressed as a boy

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: and thus unable to declare her love

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But all ends well.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How does it?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I don't know. It's a mystery

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You will never age for me, nor fade, nor die.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Nor you for me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Good bye, my love, a thousand times good bye.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Write me well.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: My lady Viola.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: My lord.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: I have spoken with your father.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: So my lord? I speak with him every day.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: My lady VIOLA.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Lord Wessex. You have been waiting.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: I am aware of it, but it is beauty's privilege.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: You flatter, my lord.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: No. I have spoken to the Queen.  Her majesty's consent is requisite when a Wessex takes a wife, and once gained, her consent is her command.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Do you intend to marry, my lord?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Your father should keep you better informed. He has bought me for you. He returns from his estates to see us married two weeks from Saturday.  You are allowed to show your pleasure.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I do not love you, my lord.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: How your mind hops about! Your father was a shopkeeper, your children will bear arms, and I will recover my fortune. That is the only matter under discussion today. You will like Virginia.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Virginia?!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Why, yes! My fortune lies in my plantations. The tobacco weed. I need four thousand pounds to fit out a ship and put my investments to work--I fancy tobacco has a future. We will not stay there long, three or four years . . .

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: But why me?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: It was your eyes. No, your lips.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Will you defy your father and your Queen?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: The Queen has consented?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: She wants to inspect you. At Greenwich, come Sunday. Be submissive, modest, grateful and brief.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I will do my duty, my lord.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Good morning, my lord!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Ah! My lady! The tide waits for no man, but I swear it would wait for you!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I meanYour Majesty, they do not, they have not, but I believe there is one who can

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Lady Viola isyoung in the world. Your Majesty is wise in it. Nature and truth are the very enemies of playacting. I'll wager my fortune.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: You look sad, my lady! Let me take you riding.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: It is not my riding day, my lord.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Bless me, I thought it was a horse.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I am going to church.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: I understand of course. It is to be expected.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: It is to be expected on a Sunday.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: And on a day of mourning. I never met the fellow but once at your house.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Mourning? Who is dead, my lord?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Oh!--dear God, I did not think it would be me to tell you. A great loss to playwriting, and to dancing.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: He is dead?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Killed last night, in a tavern! Come, then, we'll say a prayer for his soul

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Your name?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Thomas Kent. I would like to do a speech by a writer who commands the heart of every player.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Take off your hat.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: My hat?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Where did you learn how to do that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Wait there.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Are you Mr. Shakespeare?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Let me see you. Take off your hat.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you understand me?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: He is speaking about a baggage we never even meet! What will be left in your purse when he meets his Juliet?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: I am very sorry, sir, I have not seen Act Two.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Of course you have not! I have not written it!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: She tells me to keep away. She is to marry Lord Wessex. What should I do?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: If you love her, you must do what she asks.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: And break her heart and mine?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: It is only ours you can know.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: She loves me, Thomas!

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Does she say so?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No. And yet she does where the ink has run with tears. Was she weeping when she gave you this?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: I  Her letter came to me by the nurse.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Your aunt?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Yes, my aunt. But perhaps she wept a little. Tell me how you love her, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Like a sickness and its cure together.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Yes, like rain and sun, like cold and heat.  Is your lady beautiful? Since I came to visit from the country, I have not seen her close. Tell me, is she beautiful?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, if I could write the beauty of her eyes! I was born to look in them and know myself.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: And her lips?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, Thomas, her lips! The early morning rose would wither on the branch, if it could feel envy!

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: And her voice? Like lark song?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Deeper. Softer. None of your twittering larks! I would banish nightingales from her garden before they interrupt her song.

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: She sings too?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Constantly. Without doubt. And plays the lute, she has a natural ear. And her bosom--did I mention her bosom?

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: What of her bosom?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh Thomas, a pair of pippins! As round and rare as golden apples!

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: I think the lady is wise to keep your love at a distance. For what lady could live up to it close to, when her eyes and lips and voice may be no more beautiful than mine? Besides, can a lady born to wealth and noble marriage love happily with a Bankside poet and player?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes, by God! Love knows nothing of rank or riverbank! It will spark between a queen and the poor vagabond who plays the king, and their love should be minded by each, for love denied blights the soul we owe to God! So tell my lady, William Shakespeare waits for her in the garden!

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: But what of Lord Wessex?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: For one kiss, I would defy a thousand Wessexes!

turns.speaker: VIOLA AS THOMAS
turns.text: Oh!--it's--it's--oh, it's a house of ill- repute!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It is, Thomas, but of good reputation. Come, there is no harm in a drink.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: "Poet?"

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I was a poet till now, but I have seen beauty that puts my poems at one with the talking ravens at the Tower.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How do I offend, my lord?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: By coveting my property. I cannot shed blood in her house but I will cut your throat anon. You have a name?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Christopher Marlowe at your service.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Here we come at last, my lord!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Are you bringing your laundry woman?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Her chaperone. My lady's country cousin.  My, but you be a handsome gallant, just as she said! You may call me Miss Wilhelmina!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: On a more fortuitous occasion, perhaps

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, my lord, you will not shake me off, she never needed me more, I sear by your breeches!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: Is there a man?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A man, my lord?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: There was a man, poet--a theatre poet, I heard--does he come to the house?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A theatre poet?

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: An insolent penny-a-page rogue, Marlowe, he said, Christopher Marlowe--has he been to the house?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Marlowe? Oh yes, he is the one, lovely waistcoat, shame about the poetry.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: That dog!

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: You upstart inky pup! Now I will show you your place, which is in hell!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You are on my ground.

turns.speaker: WESSEX
turns.text: By God, I'll fight the lot of you

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What's his name?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't know -- Campbell or something?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: All right, just a few questions.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'd like to ask you about your hobbies.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Do a little freebasemaybe, from time to time?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Or maybe just phone out for a pizza?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Turning very briefly to the subject of corporate finance -- no, this is important. Leveraged buy-outs -- a good thing or a bad thing?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: With which of the following figures do you most closely identify: Joan of Arc, Eva Braun or Marilyn Monroe?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Squash is often used as a metaphor to represent a struggle for personal domination.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Serve.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I was trying to educate you.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Just serve.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: In the same fashion as chess.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Chess. Chess is often used as well.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Will you shut up and play.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You're a bad loser.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I haven't lost yet.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I don't want to devalue your victory, but I just want you to know: I wasn't trying to win.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Victory is the same as defeat. It's giving in to destructive competitive urges.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You learn that in your psychotherapy group?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Discussion group, Alex, discussion.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: About this guy, this Hugo person.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't have time.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm only asking what you think.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't have time to discuss it now. I don't care so long as he's not a freak.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: He made it clear.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Why, thank you, David.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Only on expenses.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: It's true. A newspaper is paying for all this. A newspaper...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, she's not in. Without waiting for any more, he replaces the reciever and walks to the door, where he picks up the mail. On his way back from the door, David emerges, ready to go to work.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Have you seen him?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Alex, I don't have the time --

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes or no, yes or no, yes or --

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I saw my grandmother, of course, but I don't suppose that counts. I mean, she was alive at the time.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Can I show you something?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Think about it.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Come on, David.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Juliet?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You mean immoral.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm only asking you both to think about it.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It's asick idea, Alex. It's sick.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But don't tell me that you're not tempted by it. Don't tell me that you're not interested. I know you well enough.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: All right, then, go ahead, telephone. Telephone the police. Try again. No one's going to stand in your way. Go ahead. Tell them there's a suitcase of money and you don't want it.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: He's still here.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He couldn't get his car started.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: When are you going to let the police know?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You call them if you want.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: And what about you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Now what else? DAVID I don't know.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: A spade, we need a spade -- I wish you would concentrate -- we need a spade if we're going to dig a pit.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: So who's going to do it?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dig the pit, I don't know.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No, not that.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Then what? Who's going to do what?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Do I? What? What? What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You know what. Who's going to do it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: We all are, David, we're all going to do it. Each of us, you, me and Juliet, will do his or her bit. Is that fair enough?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I can't do it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I don't hear this.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I won't be able to.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You're telling me you want out? Already? You're telling me you don't want the money? Hugo is going off. He smells. The flat smells. We can't wait any longer.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm just telling you I can't cut him up.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Family? Family? Friends? Drugged-up wandering suicidal search of the self fuck-ups don't have families, David.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I just thought we should discuss it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Take his legs.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Look, if I draw the short straw, then I'll do it, but I'm not going to do it just because you won't.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Finished.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But not quite.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Is that going to be deep enough?
